snippet: A 17th-century British tastemaker may have been the first female architect. An exhibition will feature Japanese design from between the two world wars.
abstract: Eve M Kahn Antiques column; architectural historian John Fitzhugh Millar is writing book First Woman Architect, about 17th-century British aristocrat Elizabeth Wilbraham, who he claims designed 400 buildings; the Japan Society in New York will display Japanese furnishings and accessories from the pre-World War II era collected by Florida anesthesiologist Dr Robert Levenson; Christie's will auction 70 bronze mirrors consigned by Chinese antiques dealer Robert H Ellsworth.
lead_paragraph: A 17th-century British tastemaker may have been the first female architect. An exhibition will feature Japanese design from between the two world wars.

headline.seo: The Case for a 17th-Century Female British Architect
headline.main: Maybe a Lady Taught Christopher Wren
headline.print_headline: Maybe a Lady Taught Christopher Wren
